intro: Guarea subspicata, commonly known as the red sandalwood, is a tropical tree native to Central and South America. It belongs to the family Meliaceae, which includes species known for their aromatic wood and medicinal properties. The plant is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish-green flowers that are followed by elongated, woody fruits. Its bark and leaves have been used in traditional medicine for their anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties. Guarea subspicata is also valued for its hard, durable wood, which has historically been used in construction and furniture-making.
